Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:

> Basic real world:  you can never anticipate how future users will use your
> software, so don't make their lives too difficult.

Extensibility is hard and does not come without cost. Every published 
method you add to a class increases the difficulty of learning that 
class more than linearly. Giving everyone everything they might possibly 
need creates baroque APIs that are extremely difficult to learn and use. 
KISS applies.

If someone presents a valid, not-too-weird use case that requires 
exposing a protected method, then by all means make the method 
protected. But don't make everything protected just because you think 
someone, somewhere might one day want to use it. If the sheer size of 
the resulting classes doesn't seem reason enough, then consider that you 
probably haven't designed the method correctly for extension in the 
first place. Methods provided in advance of an actual use case are 
unlikely to fit the use cases that do arise.

> While I sympathize with the idea of keeping as much private as possible, I
> am also a bit bothered by the patronizing feeling behind it.   Developers
> don't need baby-sitting and a lot of them are very capable to know the
> consequences of their decisions.  Reusing a protected method is dangerous --
> especially if this method has been documented with a lot of warnings -- but
> this doesn't mean it should be banned altogether.

Libraries are by their nature patronizing. If the people designing a 
library don't know more about the subject than the users of the library, 
then why should anyone use it in the first place? We can't all be 
experts in everything. We are all novices in some areas we need to work 
in. This is why we use libraries: so we can benefit from the wisdom of 
people who know more in that particular field than we do. Some of that 
wisdom includes telling people what's dangerous and what isn't. It also 
includes not exposing dangerous functionality by default without 
carefully considering whether and how much it's needed.

While some developers don't need baby-sitting, most do. In fact, let me 
dequalify that: All developers need to be baby sat. However we more 
politely call it "mentoring", " code review", and "pair programming" 
rather than baby sitting. The agile truth is, babysitting works. Of 
course we end up babysitting each other at some point, which is fine. 
The intelligence of the group often exceeds that of the sum of the 
individual members.

Agile programming is based on a humble attitude. Agility accepts that we 
don't know everything, we can't predict the future, we don't get 
anything right the first time, and we will make mistakes. It endeavors 
to minimize the damage caused by these natural aspects of being human.

The dangerous arrogance is that of the programmer who believes he's god 
and can do no wrong; that he should be immediately allowed to do 
anything he wants to to do. (I use the masculine pronoun deliberately 
here. I've yet to meet a female programmer with this particular 
personality defect, but it's epidemic among male programmers, and 
perhaps a little more common among younger ones who haven't yet had 
enough time to build a large personal catalog of really impressive 
failures.)
